bioghist.p: Founded in 1743 by Benjamin Franklin, the American Philosophical Society was the first learned society in the United States. Early members of the Society included Thomas Jefferson, David Rittenhouse, Benjamin Rush, Stephen Peter Du Ponceau, George Washington, and many other figures prominent in American history. Presently, there are over 900 members around the world, with 85% of the membership residing in the United States; foreign members represent more than two dozen countries. Members are organized into five classes: Mathematical and Physical Sciences; Biological Sciences; Social Sciences; Humanities; and The Arts, Professions, and Leaders in Public and Private Affairs. Two hundred members of the Society have received the Nobel Prize.

scopecontent.p: This collection documents the membership of the American Philosophical Society. The collection consists of nominations for membership (1980s to early 1990s), along with supporting materials such as recommendations and curricula vitae; blank ballot forms (1902-1995, with 1914 and 1923 missing); tallies of votes with aggregated comments on nominees; and sealed completed ballots. The collection also includes: statistics on nominees receiving the most votes, 1949-1984; demographic information on membership (compiled in the 1980s), such as numbers of women and African-American members, age when elected, and age and geographic location of members; office files of Randolph S. Klein, including "souvenir" correspondence with notable people, such as Linus Pauling; documents related to the production of the Yearbook and biographical memoirs; correspondence with members, vitae, and obituaries; and nominations for the Society's Council.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
